Award.AwardTitle: CICI: Data Provenance: Collaborative Research: Provenance Assurance Using Currency Primitives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data provenance is the ability to track data history including things such as where the data resided, who handled it, and what systems stored, forwarded and processed it. This research builds on the architecture of the digital currency Bitcoin. It develops distributed data ledgers - similar to bookkeeping ledgers - that maintain data history so it can't be manipulated by hackers trying to hide their activities. Data consistency guarantees that everyone gets the right answers about where, who, and what regardless of which ledger is read. This software advances the security of computing systems by making data accountable, especially for online commerce and big data ("the cloud''). It secures forensic information taken from compromised computers for further analysis. It validates whether privacy requirements are being met for medical records. The key outcome is a software prototype that implements the complete system and illustrates the ability to store, maintain, and update provenance information for real data.

A data provenance framework will be designed, prototyped, evaluated and then delivered as an Application Programmer Interface, software library, and distributed service. This work will produce a reusable distributed service architecture achieving scalability by using distributed services that maintain ledger information. The system leverages Bitcoin cryptocurrency by building on Bitcoin's block-chain architecture to maintain provenance metadata securely. It leverages existing tools for provenance data exploration and visualization. Digital signatures from both the server/system as well as the user creates dual information about possession, while distributed ledgers remove control and maintenance of metadata from the user who creates it. The prototype enables research into long-term provenance creation, maintenance, and utilization for workflows in the area of cybersecurity as well studies of how to integrate and secure provenance into existing file systems and network services. Opt-in and passive (involuntary) provenance systems will be enabled using the API, library, and distributed ledgers prototyped, enabling data provenance for systems where needed, notably high assurance cloud computing and scientific workflow systems. The tool can be used to enable reproducibility of published results from archived data and artifacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The data provenance project created a prototype for securing provenance data, known as Scrybe. Securing provenance metadata with distributed ledgers makes tampering impractical. Secure audit trails are needed to maintain trust in distributed systems, such as: data forensics, academic integrity, and security log files. For academic integrity, we provide reproducibility through reliable audit trails. Our project resulted in intellectual outcomes including: a novel mining algorithm, reliability testing, vulnerability analysis, application to multiple use cases, and two invention disclosures. We won three awards:

  • Clemson University Distinguished Postdoc Award, Lu Yu (August 2017).

  • IEEE Outstanding Research Award, ?Test of Time? For Research Contribution of the Brooks-Iyengar Algorithm with S. S. Iyengar. IEEE Cybernetics Conference, Atlanta, GA, July, 2019.

  • First Place. IEEE Blockchain for Clinical Trials Whiteboard Challenge, Orlando, FLA (Feb. 2018).

 

The Scrybe protocol uses our novel Lightweight Mining (LWM) approach. Compared to Proof-of-Work (PoW) used by Bitcoin, the use of the LWM algorithm has the benefits of blockchain integrity guarantees and non-repudiation of data, but with significantly less resource requirements than mining approaches used by cryptocurrencies. After testing, LWM is shown to be robust to malicious miners and DDoS attacks.

The Scrybe architecture's security was evaluated. Exploitation of TCP/IP vulnerabilities were tested in order to test Scrybe's reliability. DoS attacks such as SYN Flooding and its variants were used evaluate resilience under these attacks. A probabilistic analysis of the impact of these attacks were created. Attacks under the assumption of a compromised miner were conducted with IP spoofing, Randomized IP spoofing, and local area network denial (LAND) attacks on target nodes on Scrybe. We conclude that after these attacks consensus was reached despite these malicious activities.

Due to clinical regulations and research integrity requirements, our system is highly suited for clinical data documentation. Collaborating with The Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), an application of Scrybe for securely storing the provenance of data for clinical trials and medical data was done. Our application is compatible with REDCAP, which is a widely used application to capture clinical trial data and create databases and projects. Our poster presentation of this work won first place at the 2018 Blockchain for Clinical Trials whiteboard competition.

Two invention disclosures were created throughout the duration of the project. The disclosure ?Efficient Blockchain for Metadata Management? is currently undergoing an internal review process and ?Management of Data Access using blockchain? has been approved by the Clemson University Research Foundation and is currently pursuing patent application. The disclosure ?Efficient Blockchain for Metadata Management? is based off of the Scrybe architecture and software for data provenance. The disclosure ?Management of Data Access using blockchain? is for a novel application of key encryption keys (KEKs) or key wrapping in a blockchain environment for secure communication and reliable audit trail.

A graduate-level blockchain course is developed based on the materials and outcomes of the project, which will be offered in the summer semester of 2020. During 2019, PI Brooks gave six invited keynotes on his technology advances.
